story: Royal Navy set to have fewer than  frigates, warns former First Sea LordAdmiral Lord West issued the alert amid mounting tensions with China and RussiaAdmiral Lord West was First Sea Lord from  to  Image: PAByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Oct | commentsThe Royal Navy is set to have “considerably” fewer frigates to protect aircraft carriers and British waters, a former First Sea Lord warned today. Retired head of the Navy Admiral Lord West told peers the pace of government orders for new warships meant the Senior Service was at risk of dropping below  frigates. The existing fleet of Type , Duke-class vessels - some of which are  years old - is being replaced by eight, Type  City-class Global Combat Ships and five Type , light frigates. But Lord West, who commanded HMS Ardent in the  Falklands War, feared the Navy fleet would dip below  frigates.  He added: “The Government said that we would have and keep a minimum of  frigates - which is, after all, pretty damning for a maritime nation like us.“When one looks at the order rate for frigates, and the possibility of the rolling programme which so many shipyards need, one has to say that we are not going to have  frigates as we move into this decade.”He added: “As someone with an intelligence background, I would think it would be considerably less.”Defence Minister Baroness Goldie did not dispute the warning. But she told peers that “we have for the first time in  years two classes of frigate simultaneously under construction in UK shipyards”.  She added: “The Ministry of Defence expects to place an order for the batch two Type  frigates in the early s and to award a manufacture for the Fleet Solid Support ships within two years from May . “The Defence Secretary has said that he aims to have the National Flagship in the water by  or . “No decisions have yet been taken on order dates ... for the Type  frigates.” Mocking Government pledges of a British shipbuilding revival, Lord West told the Upper House: “It sounds marvellous and indeed having a Prime Minister who says that nothing does more for the security of our nation than building a warship for the Royal Navy obviously cheers a sailor like me up. “But the reality is that  months ago he made these statements and not a single order has been placed since then.”  He said that in  years “on the active list” he was “scarred” by “hearing numerous things about ships coming and never joining the Fleet”.Former Defence Minister Kevan Jones, a Labour MP who sits on the Commons Defence Select Committee and chairs the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Shipbuilding, told the Mirror: “The Government’s schedule to replace a signicant number of Type  frigates by the mid-s looks increasingly unlikely.“As such, the Royal Navy is on track to have its lowest number of frontline warships on record, by the mid-s, chiefly owing to a frigate capability gap which is all the government’s own making.”Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Royal NavyMinistry of DefenceKevan JonesArmed forcesPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: schools gave food clothes poor
story: Schools gave food and clothes to poor families due to lack of welfare safety netHard-pressed families had to rely on schools during the pandemic to get basic supplies according to a grim new report" content"https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES n _GettyImages-.jpg" width"" "" Schools had to help pupils with food and clothes during the pandemicImage:  Getty ImagesByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Oct | commentsSchools have been providing families with food and clothing during the pandemic due to weaknesses in the welfare system that urgently need repair. More families in England turned to schools for support due to pressures linked to the Covid crisis, according to research by UCLaposs Institute of Education. Schools serving populations with high levels of poverty shouldered a higher burden of dealing with food insecurity and inadequate housing. Researchers have warned that pupil premium funding, which is targeted at poorer children, does not cover the work schools do to support children living in poverty. One of the reportaposs authors Prof Alice Bradbury said: Schools are picking up the pieces from a welfare and social services system that no longer provides a real safety net for families.  For those schools, the impacts of poverty on childrenaposs lives are impossible to ignore. They interviewed  parents and staff across seven primary schools in England and found food insecurity was the most pressing priority for them all. Schools went to great s to ensure pupils received at least one meal a day - in some cases distributing food directly to the door. One headteacher said: What weaposve noticed over time was that the people who were coming to our food pantry, and we still run it now, werenapost the free school meal parents. It was this tier just above, the people whoaposd been furloughed, the people who had always had a job. Paul Whiteman, general secretary of the NAHT school leadersapos union, said: Our members tell us that childrenaposs worries leave them unable to learn and enjoy school and in need of help in the form of food, clothing and basic supplies. They are often embarrassed and ashamed. Itaposs a situation that sticks in the throat of everyone who has young peopleaposs best interests at heart. Poverty and inequality will remain entrenched in the UK unless the Government takes urgent action. Kevin Courtney, Joint General Secretary of the National Education Union, said: Schools cannot act alone and urgent action to tackle the scourge of child poverty is needed from the Government.aposWe know that even before coronavirus, . million children and young people were growing up trapped in poverty and this is only going to be made worse as the pandemic continues to take its toll.Covid- has exposed the endemic levels of poverty and inequality in the UK. A Government spokeswoman said: Throughout the pandemic we ensured schools supported the most disadvantaged children by staying open to vulnerable pupils, and delivering free school meals to those learning remotely. We have also increased pupil premium funding, expanded the holiday activities and food programme, and extended breakfast clubs, in addition to our investment of more than £ billion to make up for time lost in the classroom. But we know families have struggled, which is why we have provided billions in welfare support for the most vulnerable, made the largest investment in affordable housing in a decade and expanded mental health services to thousands more children and young people, including through our Mental Health Recovery Action Plan. title: tory peer who lent boris
story: Tory peer who lent Boris Johnson holiday home is scrutinised by his own brotherBen Goldsmith has a £,-a-day job overseeing performance and delivery at Defra - despite his brother being a minister in the same department. Angela Rayner said such jobs were "routinely abused" by the Tories to "hand out jobs to their mates"Ben Goldsmith, brother of Lord Zac Goldsmith Image: Getty ImagesByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsTory Zac Goldsmith faces fresh conflict of interest claims today, over his brother having a £,-a-day job scrutinising his government department.Millionaire environment minister Lord Goldsmith made headlines this week after it emerged Boris Johnson had jetted off for a holiday in the peer’s luxury Spanish villa.Labouraposs Deputy Leader Angela Rayner said the role of Non-executive Directorwas routinely abused by the Tories to hand out jobs to their mates. NEDs are supposed to be independent officials who “oversee performance and delivery” in a government department.Ben Goldsmith was made a NED at the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairsby then Environment Secretary Michael Gove in .But he failed to give up the job, which pays £, for  days work a year, when his brother Zac was made a DEFRA minister by Boris Johnson the following year. “Under the Tories the doors of government departments have been wide open to dodgy lobbyists, Tory donors and friends of Ministers,” Ms Rayner said.  “The role of Non-Executive Director is being routinely abused by Conservative Ministers to hand out jobs to their mates, who are £, a day of taxpayersapos money to apparently scrutinise their chums who gave them the cushy gig in the first place. Zac was allowed to keep the job despite being voted out as MP for Richmond Park in the  election, after the PM made him a Lord. DEFRA does not believe there is a conflict of interest in Ben Goldsmith’s role.People are not barred from NED roles because of political activity, as long as it is declared.There’s no suggestion either Ben or Lord Goldsmith have broken any rules.The Mirror revealed this week that Mr Johnson was soaking up the sun at a luxury Marbella hideaway owned by Lord Goldsmith, as the UK remained in the grip of a cost of living crisis.  Ms Rayner added: After the scandal of his last luxury getaway and the dodgy funding for his Downing Street flat refurbishment, the Prime Minister should simply tell us who is paying for his holiday. “The rules are clear - but Boris Johnson has a habit of breaking them. “If he is getting another freebie then the public have a right to know who is paying, how much theyaposre paying and what theyaposre getting in . news uk-news -common-spiders-found-around-"Spiders: Expert on removing them from your homeByKara ONeillReporterAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsArachnophobes, look away now. With the spider mating season here, the creepy crawlies will leave their webs and venture indoors to find a partner. And hereaposs a fact to make your skin crawl: there are over  dferent species of spiders in the UK - and all of them bite. But, luckily for us, only  of these species have enough venom that can cause harm to a human. Weaposve put together a list of  of the most common spiders youaposre likely to find around the house in the coming months, and most importantly - whether theyaposll cause you any danger. So keep your eyes peeled and a glass at the ready as you find out which spiders are friends are which are definitely foe. . Missing sector orb web spider  Also known as Zygiella x-notata, this spider is named because it spins an orb web with one full sector missing. With a size of up to mm, this arachnid is relatively small and is common around Britainaposs houses and gardens. The spider, which is not harmful to humans, can be distinguished by its pale body and legs, with silvery-grey markings on its abdomen. Usually seen indoors in the autumn and winter months, this spider prefers warmth and is most common in areas around Leicestershire and Rutland. How big are they  Up to mm Are they harmful  No, not at all . Giant house spider  Measuring a size of mm, this critter is most common in the autumn months when the males leave their webs in search of females. Often the spider youaposre likely to find in the bath, they can run extremely fast, but only for a limitedof time before they have to stop to recover from their exhaustion. These large spiders build sheet like webs and may be found in garages, sheds, attics and cavity walls where they are less likely to be disturbed. Giant house spiders do possess a potent venom and can bite, but they do not usually pose a threat to humans. How big are they  Big - mm Are they harmful  Potentially, yes - but theyaposre not at all aggressive . Daddy long legs spider  Unlike the hairy giant house spiders, these creepy crawlies have small grey bodies and long, thin legs. Although they can y in size, the Pholcus phalangioidescan potentially measure up to mm. Urban myths exist that suggest the daddy long legs spider contains the most potent venom but that their fangs arenapost strong enough to penetrate human skin. Reports on research into this theory suggests that the spiders can bite - but the venom will only deliver a brief mild burning sensation -anything at all. How big are they  Up to mm Are they harmful  No, not really . Lace web spider  Usually found on outdoor walls and fencing, these spiders will retreat inside in the autumn months to find a mate. Heavy rainfall can also force these spiders into the house, usually because they have been flooded out of their own home. They generally grow to a size of around mm and are brown with yellow markings on the abdomen. Be on your guard when you see one of these spiders, as they have been known to bite people in recent years. Bites are reported to be painful but the symptoms usually just consist of localised swelling for around  hours. How big are they  mm Are they harmful  Yes -they bite, youaposll know about it . Zebra jumping spider  These eight-legged creatures are small, reaching a size of just mm. Recognisable from their distinctive white and black markings, the move in a jerky aposstop, startapos motion. These spiders are usually seen from spring through to autumn and can be found on external walls, as well as indoors where they will enter through open doors and windows. They are more likely to flee from humans than attack them, but they can bite - although the venom is not considered medically threatening. How big are they  Small - just mm Are they harmful  No . False widow spider  Cited as Britainaposs most venomous spider the  widow already has a bad reputation. The species, also known as Steatoda nobilis, usually has an overall size of mm and is characterised by a dark brown colour and a bulbous abdomen. Adult female  widow spiders are known to have bitten humans, although they are not usually aggressive and attacks on people are rare and there are no reported UK deaths. Symptoms of a bite can range from a numb sensation to severe swelling and discomfort. In serious cases there can be ious levels of burning or chest pains, which will depend on the amount of venom injected. How big are they  mm Are they harmful  In a word, yes . Cardinal spider  The cardinal spider is the largest spider in the UK, growing to an overallof cm in some cases. Also known as Tegenaria parietina, it is known as the cardinal spider in Britain because of the legend that Cardinal Thomas Woolsey was terried by this species at Hampton Court back in the th century. Although they are mainly thought to be harmless to humans, these arachnids get a bad reputation because of their huge size, incredible speed and their nocturnal habits. Bites from these spiders are rare, and painless. How big are they  Very - cm Are they harmful  No, they look much scarier than they actually areRead more. Money spider  From the Britainaposs biggest to the smallest, money spiders grow no more than mm long, with their leg span just mm. They get their name from an old superstition thatone got stuck in your hair, it would bring you good luck and increased wealth. The money spider weaves hammock shaped webs and bites its prey to paralyse it - before wrapping it in silk and eating it. The fangs on this spider are not anywhere near big enough to penetrate human skin. How big are they  Tiny - mm Are they harmful  No, not at all . Tube web spider  As you might expect, this spider is aptly named because of the tube-shaped web it spins to catch its prey. They are often found in cracks in buildings which they will cover with silk lines while they wait in the entrance.  Originally a species from the Mediterranean regions, it can now be found in British towns including Bristol, Cornwall, Gloucester, Dover, Southampton and Sheffield, amongst others. This spider does bite and the pain has been compared to a deep injection with the sensation lasting for several hours. Despite this, the bites do not appear to have any lasting effects. How big are they  Up to mm Are they harmful  Kind of - their bite might hurt, but the pain wonapost last . Cupboard spiders  Closely related to the  black widow, the Steatoda grossa is often mistaken because of its dark colour and similarly bulbous abdomen. It usually grows to approximately mm inand its appearance can y slightly from purple to brown to black. The female can lay egg sacs at least three times a year which typically contain between  -  eggs. They have been known to bite humans, but are not usually agressive. Although injuries are minor, symptoms can include blistering and generally feeling unwell - which can last a couple of days. story: Abandoned home left to nature for over a decade is up for auction at bargain priceThe three-bedroom semi-detached home in Stafford has been empty for  years and now the local council has put it up for auction with a bargain reserve price to tempt peopleA derelict house that has been left to nature is going under the hammer for a bargain price Image: Staffordshire NewsletterByHayley ParkerTim Hanlon:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA derelict house that has been left to nature and become dilapidated after being empty for over  years is going up for auction at a price that should see bargain hunters queuing. The abandoned three-bedroom semi-detached home in Stafford has become overgrown with shrubbery and weeds after its owner died  years ago and now it will go on the market for less than £,.After a wave of complaints from neighbours about its crumbling condition, the property in Tixall Road, Stafford, will go under the hammer with a reserved price of £,, reported StokeonTrentLive.The property auction is set to take place in November and a condition of the sale will be that the buyer brings it back into use within a set time-frame. Council officials tried to track down a next of kin after the previous owner died but without success.  Stafford Borough Council applied to the secretary of state for Communities and Local Government for consent to make a Compulsory Purchase Order– which allows the local authority to take control of the house. Cabinet member for Communities and Health, Councillor Jeremy Pert, said getting the CPO was the last resort. He said: In the first instance we look to work with owners of empty or run-down properties to help bring them back in to use - and last year we assisted more than  homeowners to successfully do this. Empty properties are a wasted resource which can quickly become a blight to the community – but we have a range of measures where we can help the owner, or their next of kin, make their property habitable. Obtaining a CPO is always a last resort as it can be a y legal process which is why we would much rather work with people to remedy the situation in other ways.” He added: This has been an exceptional case in which we have gone to extraordinary s to ensure we can get this property back on the market and I am sure with the right investment and works it will make someone a nice home in the future. story: Couple discover unborn baby is an hour away from death after arriving at hospitalRichard and Danielle rushed to hospital after the expectant mum suffered stomach pains and were told their son had to be delivered eight weeks early to save his leOwen was just lb oz when he was born Image: RichardByRebecca Koncienzcy:,  Oct | commentsA aposterriedapos expectant couple discovered their unborn baby was an hour away from death when they arrived at hospital. Richard, , and Danielle, , who wanted to be known only by their first names, were told their son had to be delivered eight weeks early to save his le. They said their babyaposs heart rate was dropping after Danielle went to hospital with stomach pains. Medics discovered she had a suspected ruptured placenta and needed an emergency caesarean so baby Owen was just lb oz when he was born - the weight of a pineapple.Richard, from Wallasey, Wirral, told the Liverpool Echo : Danielle had started having pains and we went straight to hospital.  They told her they thought it was a suspected ruptured placenta - which is what it turned out to be - and Owenaposs heart rate was right down. She had emergency surgery to get him out. It was terrying, completely heartbreaking. We were toldwe had left it another hour, he wouldnapost have made it because his heart rate was so low. Tiny Owen was just lb oz - the weight of a pineapple - when he was born on October , but his dad said he is going from strength to strength.  Richard, who is also dad to Cain, , Lewis,  and stepdad to Jack, seven, said: When he was born we heard him cry like a kitten and then he was given straight to Danielle and then I held him for a bit. He was then taken to intensive care and we didnapost see him for a few hours. We had joked about having to get everything ready for when he was born just a few nights before, and now here he is. But he is doing really well, he was bigger than they expected and he is already off his oxygen and is now taking full feeds.  We canapost thank all the staff at Arrowe Park enough, they saved his le and made everything so much easier for us. Owen has not yet met his brothers and sisters due to Covid restrictions on the hospital wards at Arrowe Park. Richard said: They are made up and they canapost wait to meet him. story: Covid lateral flow tests more accurate than thought and positives should be trustedThe rapid tests, which give users a response in less than  minutes, are more than % effective at detecting any level of Covid infection, researchers have said are more accurate at detecting Covid than first thought" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _FILE-PHOTO-Students-take-coronavirus-disease-COVID--tests-at-Harris-Academy-Beckenham-in-Londo.jpg" width"" "" Lateral flow testsare more accurate at detecting Covid than first thought Image: REUTERSByLucy MiddletonAssistant news editor:,  Oct | commentsLateral flow testsare more accurate at detecting Covid than first thought - and positive results should be trusted, a new study has found. The rapid Covid tests, which give users a response in less than  minutes, have previously been criticised in comparison to PCR tests, where results are sent to a lab to be checked. Government guidance currently suggests that anyone with a positive LFT should follow it up with a PCR test to confirm they have the virus. But researchers from University College London have now found LFTs are more than % effective at detecting any level of Covid infection. They are also likely more than % effective at detecting those who are most infectious, they added.  A person might show up as negative on a LFT but positive on a PCR testthey are not a peak transmissible stage, the scientists said. They noted that the two testing methods should not be compared, as they work in dferent ways - with LFTs likely to give a positive result when someone is infectious. PCR tests instead detect genetic material which can be present in the body weeks after the person is infectious. Professor Michael Mina, from the Hard School of Public Health, said LFTs could catch nearly everyone with Covid when they are at their most infectious. He said: There is a spectrum of infectious amounts of the COVID- virus and we show that LFTs are likely to detect cases -% of the time when people are at their most infectious. The tests could achieve even % sensitivity when viral loads are at their peak and therefore catch nearly everyone who is currently a serious risk to public health. It is most likely thatsomeoneaposs LFT is negative but their PCR is positive then this is because they are not at peak transmissible stage. The study concluded that LFTs are a reliable tool in preventing the spread of Covid.  Everyone currently has free access to LFTs, with the tests being used widely to allow entry into schools, offices and work places. Prof Irene Petersen, the lead study author, urged people to trust them and stay at homethey get a positive result. She said: Previous studies comparing the reliability of lateral flow tests and PCR tests could be potentially misleading because a PCR test is a marker of having been infected at some point within a certain window of time and does not necessarily mean someone is infectious when testing positive. She added that her husband was suffering from heightened anxiety because of the pandemic. She added: He said he felt trapped. Our main thing we did together as a couple was go to the pub for a pint. story: Man may have to pay £, to neighbour as Ring doorbell invades her privacyDr Mary Fairhurst told Oxford County Court how she felt harassed by her neighbour Jon Woodard after he set up four Amazon Ring doorbell devices around his property to deter car thieves use of his front door camera breaches the privacy of Doctor Mary Fairhurst, his neighbour" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _NWS-JGL-WOODARD--.jpg" width"" "" A judge has found that Jon Woodardsuse of his front door camera breaches the privacy of Doctor Mary Fairhurst, his neighbour Image: dmg media LicensingByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA doctor is set to be awarded up to £, after a judge ruled her neighbouraposs smart doorbell camera breaches her privacy. Jon Woodardaposs use of Amazon Ring doorbell cameras have been found to breach the privacy of Doctor Mary Fairhurstaposs in a landmark legal case. Dr Fairhurst claims Mr Woodardaposs camera use amounted to harassment and says it forced her to move out of her home in Thame, Oxfordshire. She says the internet-connected gadgets - sold by Amazon - were intrusive and a judge agreed. The doorbell connects to the Wi and tells the homeowner when theyaposre out via smartphone when a visitor turns up on the doorstep. Using an app, the owner can watch visitors through the camera and talk to them via the doorbellaposs microphone.Mr Woodard - who works as an audio-visual technician - says he fitted four cameras around his property, MailOnline reports. Two of the devices were dummies and he used them to deter car thieves after an attempted theft in , he said. Dr Fairhurst - who is the director of a holistic healthcare company - told Oxford County Court she considered the devices continuous visual surveillance. More than , people in the UK own a Ring doorbell, meaning the ruling yesterday could pave the way for similar cases across the country. The neighbours were peaceful until recently when the doctor claims Mr Woodard became aggressive when she told him she was unhappy about the doorbell, Oxford County Court heard. Judge Melissa Clarke told the court yesterday Mr Woodard had breached the Data Protection Act  and UK GDPR laws. The ruling now entitles Dr Fairhurst to compensation and Mr Woodard is banned from recording her with his surveillance cameras. Any images or audio files of Dr Fairhurst stored on the devices are now considered her personal data. The judge also found that Mr Woodard - considered a data controller by the Information Commissioner - failed to store Dr Fairhurstaposs data in a fair or transparent way. He had also sought to actively mislead Dr Fairhurst about the way the cameras worked and what data they captured. Judge Clarke said Mr Woodard had collected the doctoraposs personal data by recording her beyond the boundaries of his property.  Another camera was installed in Mr Woodardaposs driveway - which he claimed was a dummy. The judge disagreed and said this camera captured images and audio on Dr Fairhurstaposs property including her gate, garden and car parking spaces. She also said crime prevention was achievable with something less than the Ring device. Judge Clarke added the cameraaposs audio range canapost be considered reasonable for crime prevention. Mr Woodard told the Mail after the remote hearing he was extremely disappointed and shocked by the ruling. He told the Mail: I purchased a ring doorbell and ring motion activated camera in , in good faith to protect my property and vehicles. To now be told these are harassment devices feels like a joke and I myself feel like I am being harassed. Many of my neighbours have cameras and smart doorbells.  He added the ruling contradicts police advice. Forces up and down the country are known to appeal for the public to hand over smart doorbell, CCTV and dashcam footage to help bolster evidence to assist arrests for thieves, dangerous drivers, and violent criminals. Mr Woodard also said he worries that tens of thousands of homeowners with similar devices may now be targeted in the same way. Amazon-owned Ring has now asked its customers to make visitors aware they are being recorded in response to the landmark ruling. A spokesperson for the Calornia-based company told The Mail: We strongly encourage our customers to respect their neighboursapos privacy and comply with any applicable laws when using their Ring device. Weaposve put features in place across all our devices to ensure privacy, security, and user control remain front and centre - including customisable Privacy Zones to block out aposoff-limitapos areas, Motion Zones to control the areas customers want their Ring device to detect motion and Audio Toggle to turn audio on and off. Damages payable to Dr Fairhurt are expected to be revealed during a November court date, but she could be awarded £,. The ruling means that anyone with the same Ring doorbell who is accused of filming people outside their property could be subject of a similar lawsuit over breaching the privacy of their neighbours. story: Dr Esho: I want to give people who look like me access to careers in medicineNetflix star Dr Tijion Esho is a leading cosmetic doctor and has come a long way from feeling out of place in medical school due to his black heritage and working class upbringingNetflix star Dr Tijion Esho is a leading cosmetic doctor and has come a long way Image: Dr EshoByNaimah Archibald-Powell:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsHe is one of Britain’s most celebrated cosmetic doctors whose treatments have helped people across the country to feel beautul and confident. Dr Tijion Esho has been the voted the UK’s best aesthetics doctor every year since  and was this year named most influential doctor in the beauty industry. With the rich and famous flocking to his clinic for treatments like his -ct gold champagne facial, he is known to many as the A-list’s best kept secret. But while he helps many feel confident in their own skin, Dr Tijon - whose popular ESHO brand has made facials available to everyone - often felt out of place as he pursued his career in the cosmetics industry.  At medical school he was one of only two black students in his year: “I remember a girl coming up to me and she was just staring at me and she said, ‘I know this really sounds weird, but you’re the first black person I’ve seen in real le and not on TV’. “I just thought that was weird, what world am I coming into  Coming from a erse community to here where people were so limited. Also at the time. I was worried in terms of classism because a lot of people there were from generations of doctors. I was like, am I on the back foot here  “In the end what showed through was talent. When you’re working through, you gain respect and you move through and you blaze your own path through things.” Growing up in North London’s Edmonton, he knows all too well the importance of having positive role models and exposure to dferent career paths. His parents emigrated from Nigeria and they were made to sacrice their own dreams in order to earn enough money to support their children.  “My parents came here in their s from Nigeria and they had me and then had my sister. They were educated people, my Dad was an accountant and my Mum was a teacher but when they came over here their qualications weren’t recognised and they worked in a tiling factory. We lived in council state housing. They did a lot of sacricing to put me and my sister through education. “My Dad always said, ‘you have opportunities here son, you have to grab it with both hands’, and so I’ve never wanted to sit on my hands. I’ve always wanted to push to do as much as I can because then I feel like I’m paying back my parents for the opportunities and the sacrices they made for us.” Initially wanting to pursue a career in graphic design, Tijion’s plans were challenged by his Dad who wanted his son to chase something in STEM.The UK began celebrating Black History Month, an idea first spawned in the United States and then also adopted by European countries including Ireland and the Netherlands, in October . Black History Month helps give context to modern le and the countryaposs history, while championing the experiences and celebrating the contributions of Black Britons here in the UK. The observation was first organised through the leadership of Ghanaian-born analyst Akyaaba Addai-Sebo. He served as a coordinator of special projects for the Greater London Council. Consequently, Akyaaba created a plan aiming to recognise the contributions of African, Asian and Caribbean people to the economic, cultural and political le in the UK. “My dad was said you can pick between being a doctor, a dentist, a lawyer, engineer or an accountant. These are careers where you’ll have security in the future’. “We didn’t see eye to eye at that point because I couldn’t understand why he would push me from something that I loved to these things that I knew nothing about. In retrospect as an adult looking at it, I can see he was seeing the sacrices he had to make, and was trying to get me in a position to be secure enough to provide for a family. “When I went on work experience, I saw the art in what the surgeon was doing on people’s faces and bodies. I saw it and I was amazed and I thought okay, we have a compromise here. Plastics became my thing because I loved the art, I loved the finesse and the attention to detail.” Turning down a private school scholarship in favour of going to the local state school with his friends, Tijion says his Dad pushed him and enabled him to get the million pound career that he has today. “If it wasn’t for my parents, medical school might not have happened because at school I was discouraged, I actually wasn’t pushed. I remember meeting the head of the year when my dad and I said medicine was the way to go and her saying, ‘Have you got any alternatives, because that might be a bit dficult’. There wasn’t a push to it or a ‘let’s give you access to it.’ It was a no. My dad was hyper aware that for a lot of young black guys, the push was towards sports.” Now the doctor wants to build a laboratory for his products in the UK that will offer black students career inspiration and opportunities in both medicine and pharmaceutical fields.  “I’m not just doing this for my family or me, I’m doing this on a community level now and I need to try and do my best to give opportunities to people like me to have access.” The drive to inspire can be heavy though with an emphasis on perfection, precision and appearances - much like cosmetic surgery itself. “If there’s a mistake, you’re no longer the UK’s leading cosmetic surgeon, you are the Nigerian doctor. I think every black parent tells you that you’re going to be scrutinised dferently. You are going to be judged dferently, you have to work hard and we know that early. We’re told that so early.” Social media trolls come with the territory too with Tijion receiving abuse aimed at himself, his son Roman, , and his partner Laura.  “When people saw that my partner was white and my son was mixed race, some people took that as a negative thing. “When my son was born, I got these inboxes from unnamed accounts and they said, ‘Your kid, even though he’s half white, he could never not be black, he’s still a monkey.’ “I built a thick skin for things coming towards me but for stuff to come towards my missus and my baby  That really affected me because all you want to do is protect them and for people to love them.” Comment MORE ON EducationSchoolsCosmetic surgeryPlastic surgeryFacialsBlack History Month" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: how often you should clean
story: How often you should clean your toilet, light switches and change the beddingPaul Morris, founder of hygiene specialist Addmaster, previously brought together the perfect cleaning schedule to help you tackle the chores this autumnA recent survey found that % of people in the UK feel anxious when their house is untidyImage: Getty ImagesByNeil Shaw:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThough toilets are often deemed to be the dirtiest part of the house, they aren’t as filthy as you may think. And you may be surprised to learn that both light switches and TV remote controls are amongst the filthiest surfaces in the average household.Paul Morris, founder of hygiene specialist Addmaster, has previously put together the perfect cleaning schedule to help you tackle the chores this autumn. He teamed up with online blind store  Blinds, which found in a recent survey that % of people in the UK feel anxious when their house is untidy, reports Hull Live. When to clean your…Toilet: Once a week The ceramic surface makes them really easy to clean so scrubbing your toilet once a week with bleach or disinfectant in the bowl is enough to keep good hygiene levels. Just be sure to put the lid down before you flush - to avoid contaminating the entire bathroom.Kitchen surfaces: Every time you use themCleaning your kitchen surface as you go will help to reduce a huge workload in the long run. Spray with disinfectant to kill any nasty bacteria, both before and after preparing a meal.Carpet:  to  times a week Everyone loves the warmth and comfort of a carpet, but you must remember that they harbour a lot of bacteria. Not only that - they are often home to other nasties such as dust mites which can cause asthma. Vacuum regularly and to take off your outdoor shoes before walking on your carpet.Bedding: Once a week Paul recommends that you wash your bedding above  degrees to kill any bacteria. Unless you sweat a lot at night or enjoy sleeping in the nude, once a week at  degrees is appropriate - and isn’t too time-consuming. To lessen the need to change your sheets as often, a mattress protector is advised.Sinks: Daily when usedAgain, a quick clean of your ceramic sink is a good way to chip away at chores throughout the week. The plug area can be an unseen danger and hotspot for bacteria and dirt: one that can be easily combated with permanent antimicrobial protection.Remote control and light switches: Once a weekBoth light switches and TV remote controls are amongst the filthiest surfaces in the average household. By giving them a quick wipe once a week you’ll reduce risks of bacterial contamination by a signicant amount - a simple way to keep your home hygienic. story: Brits urged to buy NOW for Christmas - whats actually in short supply and whyExperts say supplies of Christmas toys and gts will be “materially constrained” this year, with one predicting that Black Friday and January sales will be mutedGetting your orders in early may prove to be a wise move Image: Dinendra Haria LNPByMirror:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Wannabee artist Boris Johnson may paint a picture that shortages are no big issue – but thousands of firms say otherwise.They are battling staff and stock shortages but have so far largely shielded customers. It’s why supermarkets are, on the whole, fully stocked. Yet the gaps are appearing. There will be smaller ranges, a bit less choice, and some products going out of stock. It’s about time the PM showed proper leadership and took action.What products are in short supply Everything from fizzy drinks and certain fresh produce to new cars.What is causing these major issues  There’s a iety of reasons, some related to the Covid crisis, others worsened by Brexit.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Among the most pressing is a lack of HGV drivers – put at , – caused by a combination of long-term poor pay and conditions, delays in driver training because of the pandemic, EU drivers going home because of Brexit and tax changes.This shortage of truckers is the main reason for logjams at ports, with shipping containers left sitting on the dockside. Firms waiting for the shipments are being hit twice, with “rent” while the containers are heldup and delays getting stock. How widespread are the shortages If you go to shops, the shelves are mostly filled. But behind the scenes retailers are working flat out to tackle supply chain issues. One solution has been to reduce ranges, which may limit choice but still means there is plenty of most of our favourite items.Will there be shortages at Christmas Most experts believe there will be shortages of certain products but, again, it will be most likely mean smaller ranges and, as in most years, certain best-selling products being in limited supply.Isn’t it in retailers’ interest to get us to buy early  Possibly, and experts are saying there could be an element ofthat going on here. title: mans message bottle comes back
story: Mans message in a bottle comes back to him  years after throwing it in oceanSince sending the bottle off into the ocean, Alex tragically lost his mum, Valerie Melling, to cancer. He was now "in disbelief" that their message was now safely back in his handsAlex Melling as a child with mum Valerie, dad Graham and brother FreddieByLouisa Gregson:,  Oct | commentsA Manchester man is in disbelief upon having a message in a bottle he threw out to sea as a six-year-old ed to him more than two decades later.Alex Melling said he was scrolling through a local community Facebook group when a mention of his old childhood address caught his eye.Alex, who is now , said he scrolled back up and then saw his name mentioned in a post that he just could not quite believe.According to the Manchester Evening News, the post was written by a man called Rex Winter, who claimed he was trying to track down an Alex at that address after his son and daughter had discovered a message in a bottle in a remote bay in Scotland.The post read - aposHelp with a Message in a Bottle: This summer my kids found a message in a bottle on a remote beach in the west of Scotland. It seemed to be old, and the message inside appeared to have been written by a child. The message inside was from somebody called Alex,who gave an address of  Gilbert Street, Hindley. There was no other information, date or otherwise.  My daughter wrote to Alex at that address some time ago but has had no reply. He she may well have moved and or the house is now unoccupied. I donapost knowthe bottle is  years old or  years old, but Iaposm sure that Alex would be interested to learn where it ended-up!” The post went on to ask that anyone who could “know who Alex might be”, get in touch. Alex, who had lived at that address as a child but had moved when he was aged , responded via Facebook. It transpired that Rex’s daughter, -year-old Izzy, had found the bottle while on holiday with her brother and their friends. Izzy, who lives in Newcastle, said: We were camping in Scotland and had taken a boat out in Garlieston, around Wigton Bay.  We anchored the boat and went to explore in the caves. Freddie found the bottle washed up and we could see a message in it. The message was written on the back of a childaposs birthday party invitation and read: aposIf found pleaseto  Gilbert Street, Hindley. Thank You. Please address to Alex.apos Izzy says they wrote to the address but when they received no response, their dad Rex, a solicitor, , decided to try and find Alex on Facebook. Rex got “really into it”, Izzy said, finding and posting in a Facebook group called Hindley Residents. There was much excitement when Alex got in touch and they posted the bottle back to him. I was doing my homework and I got a message from my dad saying: I found him,” Izzy said. We were just like: aposwowapos. Since sending the bottle off into the ocean, Alex tragically lost his mum, Valerie Melling, to cancer. He was now in disbelief that their message was now safely back in his hands. Alex says the bottle was posted to him with a bottle of Jack Daniels as a celebratory gt. He has written a letter of thanks to the Winter family, he said, Alex says his grandmother Lilian Wetherby, , confirmed the message was in his mumaposs handwriting and adate on the invitation was  - when Alex would have been aged six. He says his grandma was very emotional when she saw the handwriting of her daughter, who died of cancer aged just . Alex says he has a vague recollection of throwing the message to sea, although he canapost remember where they were. Reading my mumaposs note was really nice as it was her handwriting and her words,” he added. My brother Daniel was buzzing and my grandma was really emotional. I will be keeping the bottle forever now with some other keepsakes. I canapost quite believe it. title: mum left mortified misunderstanding after
story: Mum left mortied by misunderstanding after posing naked for charity calendarClare Pert bravely stripped off in front of the cameras for a calendar to raise money for a local hospice - but realised she had made a huge mistake when she saw the other monthsClares friends have never let her live the mistake downByLuke MatthewsSenior Audience Writer:,  Oct | commentsA mum says she was left mortied after posing naked for a charity calendar - only to realise she was supposed to be fully clothed when the pictures were released. Clare Pert and her friends had arranged to put together the calendar to raise money for a local hospice and the mum bravely modelled for her month of April, with only a yellow duck teddy protecting her modesty. But when the group later sat down to review their creation together, it quickly dawned on Clare as they looked through January, February and Marchaposs photos that she had screwed up massively. The business analyst from Leeds had assumed it was a naked calendar after it was mentioned briefly in passing, but the rest of her friends posed fully clothed or in swimsuits, and they now jokingly warn Clare not to turn up starkers every time they make plans.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Clare was recently reminded of the embarrassing incident, which took place back in , when it came up as a Facebook memory and she decided to embrace her initial embarrassment by sharing the story in a viral post. The mum to three boys, who blames the misunderstanding on baby brain having been -weeks pregnant at the time, said: I’d never done a naked photoshoot before. And, come to think of it, I now know none of my friends have either. I chose to be April as that was when my son was due. My turn came, and I went into the photographer, took all my clothes off and proudly announced: aposWhere do you want me !apos I couldnapost understand why the photographer and his we were so shocked - but I put it down to me being the only pregnant lady maybe. They had just seen January, February and Marchaposs lady gardens, so why was I any dferent   Roll forward a week, I sit down with my  other friends, all looking through the pictures. January, February and March came, by then I knew I had screwed up massively - they all had either clothes or swimwear on. I was mortied seeing myself absolutely starkers, with just a massive yellow chick covering my bits, I will never live that down. Clare turned up late to the photoshoot and being in a rush, she says she didnapost think to checkanyone  was getting their kit off and hurriedly stripped off and headed into the studio. Itaposs a mistake the mum has never been allowed to forget as it still remains her friendsapos favourite topic of conversation.  The mishap recently popped back up on Facebook as a memory and - after a couple of glasses of wine - Clare decided it was the right time to give everyone  a laugh.The post has since gone viral with more than , likes and , comments, as other people replied with their own embarrassing moments in a show of support. Clare added: I literally just spent all day reading through the comments and the funny stories and the messages. I didn’t see one negative message and everyone was so nice - I shared it because it was such a stupid thing to do, and it took off!Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Viral" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news prince-george-confused-annoyed-state-"Prince William discusses George litter picking at schoolByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsPrince William has revealed how his eight year old son Prince George has become a bit confused and annoyed at the state of the planet during litter picking sessions. The Duke went on to discuss his worries about his son’s generation who might still be talking about climate change in  years’ time, when it will be too late As part of a new BBC podcast, William said: So George at school recently has been doing litter picking and I didnapost realise but talking to him the other day he was already showing that he was getting a bit confused and a bit sort of annoyed by the fact they went out litter picking one day and then the very next day they did the same route, same time and pretty much all the same litter they picked up back again. And I think that for him he was trying to understand how and where it all came from. He couldnapost understand, heaposs like, aposwell, we cleaned this. Why has it not gone away ’ The future king told the podcast that he was concerned that George and his generation might still be talking about climate change in decades to come.  He added: But it shouldnapost be that thereaposs a third generation now coming along having to ramp it up even more. And you know, for me, it would be an absolute disasterGeorge is sat here talking to you or your successor, you know in like  years’ time, whatever, still saying the same thing, because by then we will be too late.William also slammed billionaire space tourists such as Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk for pursuing space travel instead of helping to solve the climate crisis.In an impassioned plea to two of the world’s richest men, both worth around £billion each, the Duke of Cambridge said: “We need some of the world’s greatest brains and minds fixed on trying to repair this planet, not trying to find the next place to go and live.” A new age space race between Amazon founder Bezos’s Blue Origin and Tesla founder Musk has emerged pitting two of the world’s richest and brainiest men against each other. In contrast, father-of-three William has said he is being motivated with his environmental work to “use my little bit of influence” to help change the world for future generations. “I want the things that I’ve enjoyed – the outdoor le, nature, the environment – I want that to be there for my children, and not just my children but everyone ’s children. “If we’re not careful we’re robbing from our children’s future through what we do now. And I think that’s not fair. I want to use my little bit of influence   profile to highlight incredible people doing incredible things and will genuinely help fix some of these problems.” His comments, which will be broadcast today in an interview on the BBC Newscast podcast, come as Hollywood actor William Shatner yesterday became the oldest person to go to space.The -year-old, who played Captain James T Kirk in the Star Trek films and TV series, took off from the Texas desert with three other iniduals in a mission paid for by Bezos. Mr Shatneraposs trip on the rocket lasted about  minutes, while in July Bezos made his own  minute flight into space in his self funded rocket New Shepard saying it was his “best day ever! walking stick, the second time sheaposs been seen with it publicly in  years. Her Majesty was visiting the Welsh Parliament in Cardf with her son Charles, the Prince of Wales, and his we Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall. She wore a pink coat and hat combination and was not sporting a mask as she shook hands with dignitaries. Clasped in her hand was a walking stick she was last seen holding two days ago at a service to mark the th anniversary of the Royal British Legion. Before that the Queen, , was last spotted in public using the same walking aid back in January , when she relied on it to assist her walking following a knee operation. On Tuesday Her Majesty was handed the stick after stepping from her state limousine, and appeared to be moving freely as she walked to her seat for the start of the service. She used the stick again as she left. A jam-packed schedule was put on for the Queen, Charles and Camilla at the Parliament building, which is called Senedd Cymru in Welsh.  The Welsh and British national anthems were played to welcome the royals before a royal salute was given. The Royal Navy with the band of the Royal Marines was in position in front of the Senedd. Also greeting the trio were school children waving Welsh flags. The royals were due to meet party leaders and listen to a musical performance given by the Welsh National Youth Opera. The Queen, Charles and Camilla were there for the opening ceremony of the sixth session of the Senedd. Back in  the head of state was seen using a walking stick as she left King Edward VII Hospital in London.  Back then she opted for a heavy duty pole following the operation, before wielding a wooden support two weeks later at Sandringham. Paul Simons, the owner of London-based business WalkingSticks, told Mail Online that the Queen was using a more of a telescopic walking pole with trigger grip and wrist loop this week. news uk-news stepmum-ate-ice-cream-boy-"Birmingham: Flowers left at house where six year old boy diedByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct A stepmum ate ice cream and sat in a hot tub while a little boy was locked in a hallway for  hours over two days before he died, a jury was told. Arthur Labinjo-Hughes, six, collapsed with fatal injuries at a home after he was forced to spend marathon stints in front of the front door, Coventry Crown Court heard. It was also claimed little Arthur was made to sleep on the floor in the living room despite the fact there were empty beds upstairs. Prosecutors say it was part of a campaign of cruelty he was allegedly subjected to before being unlawfully killed. Arthuraposs father Thomas Hughes, , and his partner Emma Tustin, , deny murder and multiple counts of child cruelty. Tustin has admitted one child cruelty offence.  During the fourth day of the trial on Tuesday, prosecutor Jonas Hankin alleged the couple assaulted Arthur, isolated him from the family, forced him to stand up for prolonged periods of time, denied him food and drink as well as poisoned him with salt. Mr Hankin told the jury about the events leading up to Arthuraposs collapse on June  last year. On June , Arthur spent a total of  hours and  minutes in the hallway, the court heard. CCTV of Tustin eating a McDonaldaposs in the living room was shown to the court as Arthur ate lunch a few feet away in the hall.  At one point, Tustin allegedly sent Hughes an audio clip of him crying along with a text message reading: P***ed me off he has. Paused Corrie. Hughes allegedly replied: Kid is a selfish little c*** Iaposll dash my food off his head. Arthur then spent a further  hours and  minutes in the hallway on June , the court heard. The jury watched CCTV from the home of the couple eating ice cream cones as well as sitting in the hot tub.  Earlier that day, Tustin allegedly texted Hughes accusing Arthur of making my le hell and claiming she was slowly but surely cracking. By the afternoon, it appeared Hughes was trying to seduce Tustin to the bedroom by messaging her saying he was naked and waiting for you to take my soul. Mr Hankin then read a text message to the court from June  that was sent from Tustin to Hughes, which said: Still screaming. He said he hates me. Heaposs gonna spit his sandwich out on the floor when he has it. Loves his nan more than you.  Heaposs just said he donapost f***ing care now saying haha because I said Iaposm telling you. He said you wonapost believe me, you will believe him like before. Now screamed heaposs gonna tell his mom to kill me. Just on the phone to Affy. He said: aposGlad we arenapost going because I was going to be naughty all day for you. Mr Hankin told the court Tustin was the only possible perpetrator behind the alleged fatal assault on Arthur on June  because she was the only one at home looking after him. He argued Hughes shares culpability because he intentionally encouraged the killing. news uk-news super-cold-sweeping-uk-expert-"Why does it feel like Im having the worst cold ever  A GP ExplainsByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsCases of the common cold are surging as experts warn low levels of natural immunity are to blame. Social media is seeing users increasingly talking about having caught a “Super Cold” as Covid- tests come back negative. Prof Neil Mabbott, expert at the University of Edinburgh, said: “This highlights the power of the lockdown, mask wearing, social distancing and sanitation measures introduced in response to the pandemic.“Not only was this very effective in reducing transmission of the coronavirus within the community, but at the same time it had the additional benefit of reducing the spread of colds and other common transmissible diseases.“As these measures are eased and people start mixing more indoors and travelling on public transport we can expect to see a signicant rise in colds and other respiratory diseases.”  Retail worker Rebecca London, , from Bournemouth, caught what she calls “the worst cold ever” at a festival.A normal cold for her would have “a runny nose, sneezing, a bit of a sore throat and feeling a bit rundown”.“Nothing like this,” she told the BBC. “I barely slept, I’d wake up in the night just coughing, a constantly runny nose and feeling so tired,” she adds. Rebecca did lateral flow tests and got negative results, but has been ill for more than a week, and was left wondering “ it’s ever going to end”.  Prof Alex Richter, of Birmingham University, said: “It is impossible to tell the dference between a cold and Covid- clinically. “They present so similarly that only PCR testing can dferentiate between the two. Lateral flow testing can help with screening, butsomeone has symptoms then they should go for a PCR swab test.” “It is unlikely we are seeing the circulation of a aposSuper Coldapos,” Prof Mabbott added. “Rather our immune systems have had limited exposure to colds over the past  months, so our immunity to these diseases will have waned during this period and will be less effective against colds than would be expected normally.” Prof Alan McNally, is Professor of Microbial Evolutionary Genomics at the University of Birmingham and was Infectious Disease lead at the Milton Keynes Lighthouse Lab. He said: “If you have any symptoms of respiratory infection you should stay at home to prevent transmission and get a test done for Covid- to rule in or out. because cases are already soaring abroad, a top expert has warned. Dr John McCauley says spiralling cases in China, India and Croatia could indicate an earlier wave of infections in the UK this year. It comes amid a warning that immunity against bugs is so low after Covid lockdowns that the flu could kill , people. The UKaposs flu season usually begins in September and ends in March but the NHS usually starts to feel the pressure in January. However Dr McCauley - a prominent flu scientist based at Londonaposs Francis Crick Institute - says Brits should prepare for an earlier surge in cases due to a rise in infections overseas. He told MailOnline that Croatia, China and India had all experienced a rise in infections.It’s over the next few weeks that we will be able to tellwhat we are seeing now is sustained. If it is, we might expect an early flu season, he added. There is flu being picked up in some places, but whether it is spreading in some of theseis not known for certain. His warning comes as Dr Jenny Harries, chief executive of the UK Health Security Agency, fears Brits will face a deadly double act of Covid and flu this winter due to waning immunity. Dr Harries said the public should be worried about the flu each winter. Speaking to Trevor Phillips on Sky she warned that those who catch both illnesses at the same time are twice as likely to die than patients with Covid alone. She said: On average over the past five years, around , people have died [per year] with flu-related conditions.  The important thing about this winter is that weaposre likely to see flu, for the first time in any real numbers, co-circulating with Covid. The risks of both together still remain. The early evidence suggests youaposre twice as likely to die from the two together than just Covid alone. Last week Professor Jonathan Van-Tam, Deputy chief medical officer, warned that immunity against bugs is so low after lockdowns that the flu could kill , people. He said: “Not many people got flu last year because of Covid restrictions, so there isn’t as much natural immunity as usual. “We will see flu circulate this winter. It might be higher than usual and that makes it a signicant public health concern. Covid- will still be circulating and with more people mixing indoors, sadly some increases are possible. For the first time we will have Covid- and flu co-circulating. Urging people to get the Covid jab, he added: “We need to take this seriously and defend ourselves and the NHS by getting the annual flu jab and the Covid- booster when called. It comes on top of residents raising over £, in record time from a community share offer to buy The Old Forge in the Scottish Highlands. The pub can only be reached by boat or walking  miles over several mountains over  feet - from the nearest road. The community of just over  people on the west coast at Knoydart have been so successful with a bold fundraising campaign to purchase the distant drinking hole that it called time on its share offer a week early - by which point they had raised £, from  members! news uk-news women-wearing-masks-hide-skin-"Keep up ‘second nature’ behaviour like mask-wearing, campaign urgesByAndrew Young:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct Millions of British women liked wearing a mask during the pandemic – as it disguised their skin, according to a poll. Researchers found that  percent of women have gone to great s throughout their lives to cover up spots, including wearing roll neck jumpers in summer and wrapping scarfs around their face. And over the past  months, more than half of the , women polled have enjoyed covering their faces with masks. Other tricks regularly deployed to hide bad skins include wearing hair loosely, growing a fringe and walking with their head down.  Half have also tried covering acne or spots up with layers of makeup, but fear it just makes things worse. Did you enjoy wearing a mask  Have your say in the comment section  Nearly three-quartersof women arenapost happy with their skin and have tried six products to attempt to fix it. And the average woman spends  minutes caring for her skin each day, spending an average of £ in the last year. The survey was commissioned by Polish dermacosmetics skincare brand Tolpa, which has launched its facial skincare products in the UK.  Kadeeja Sel Khan, an ambassador for Tolpa’s Nothing to Hide campaign, said: “It’s hard to see so many women struggle with the look of their skin, even when it’s such a natural and normal thing that we all go through.“I have acne-prone and very sensitive skin and it can definitely get my mood down sometimes. “Like many women, I used to find myself trying to hide my skin – but I have embraced the natural look and began using products that show the reality behind the filter, that actually work, which has made a huge dference.”  The survey also found  percent of women consider their skin to be the most important part of their appearance. Concerningly,  percent said there has been a time when they haven’t left their house because of their skin, and one in ten have even lost out on opportunities because of their spots. Furthermore,  percent have turned to home-made remedies including putting toothpaste on a spot, and honey face masks and apple cider vinegar in a bid to clear their skin.  And while  percent are dubious that these at home remedies work, they are willing to try anything. Cucumber and teabags on eyes, toothpaste on spots and OTC antiseptics top the list of the most popular DIY products. Charcoal and glue facemasks, surgical spirit and apple cider vinegar toner are also methods women commonly use. But  percent said they didn’t notice a dference in their skin after using an at-home remedy, and some even said it made their skin worse.  The research, carried out via OnePoll, shows three in ten tried these remedies as they were desperate to have better skin. It also emerged that  percent look for products that combine natural and scientically proven ingredients, while  percent are always on the look out for skincare with innovative ingredients. Dr Alia Ahmed, independent consultant dermatologist to Tolpa, said: “It’s clear people use these remedies out of desperation, but they may cause further problems, so I usually advise against this. “It’s great that people are now looking for products that combine the best from nature with scientically proven ingredients, as this is something I recommend. “Acne affects quality of le and has considerable psychological, social and emotional impact. “As the stats show, sadly, the psychological impact of acne affects several aspects of daily le, including the ability to socialise, and can limit occupational opportunities.”To find out more, visit the Lloyds Pharmacy page.Top  home remedies for spotsCucumber on eyes Toothpaste on spots Tea bags on eyes OTC antisepticsHoney face masks Lemon juice Sugar scrub Oat face mask Facial wash made from essential oils Coconut oil to remove makeup Apple cider vinegar toner Baking soda face scrub Fruit mask Turmeric face mask Charcoal and glue facemasksMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON AcneSkincare" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Doctor in vaccine plea after mum-of-three loses her feet and hands during Covid battleDr Wesley Ely posted a video of -year-old Autumn Nugent walking with her new prosthetic legs after medics were forced to amputate her limb due to Covid complicationsAutumn Nugent lost her feet and hands Image: WesElyMD TwitterByLorraine King:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA doctor has shared a mumaposs harrowing battle with Covid which resulted in her losing both her hands and feet as he urged people to get vaccinated. Dr Wesley Ely from Nashville, US, posted a video of -year-old Autumn Nugent walking with her new prosthetic legs after medics were forced to amputate her limbs due to complications from the virus. He said Autumn pleaded with him to share her story in a desperate bid to encourage others to get the jab. Dr Ely captioned the video: “Covid took her hands and feet. “I cried when she sent me this yesterday: Her physical resilience and mental fortitude are my inspiration.” Issuing an emotional vaccine plea on behalf of Autumn, he tweeted: “She sent this of her walking with new legs and said to tell you…Blood clots of Covid can be prevented with a vaccine!”  Dr Ely previously released a series of tweets detailing the mum-of-threeaposs devastating journey with Covid- as she requested. He wrote: “Covid- is a disease of blood vessels that can affect your lungs, heart, brain, or any organ. Blood clotting sucks le from vital organs. “This patient asked to have her story shared so that others may learn and seek vaccination.” The medic explained that complications from the virus caused blood clots in Autumnaposs arms and legs, resulting in wounds that resembled burns. “It took nurses many hours each day to change her wounds,” he said. As Autumn continue to battle with the virus Dr Ely said it became clear that there would be a costshe was to survive. “She was going to live, and we were all thrilled. Still, it was sad to think that this young woman would lose her hands and feet as they continued to dry up, leless and still,” he said. Dr Ely posted a photo of Autumn with a nurse in the hospital courtyard which was taken a week after she underwent the amputations. He said: “Her desire for le became a huge inspiration to all of us. I gained way more from her than she ever gained from me. Autumn had to endure gruelling physical therapy while taking more than  dferent medications every day in the weeks that followed which meant she had to overcome immense physical and mental barriers. “Here you can see her during rehabilitation just after she finished doing some amazing planks. Even with healing wounds, she was doing  minutes of planking – such is her physical and mental strength!” Dr Ely wrote about her progress. Autumn was gted a set of prosthetics with her sister’s and kidsapos names on them to give her hope and motivation during her recovery.  Dr Ely revealed that he and Autumn have become close through her journey and she even calls him dad. He said: “I call her my daughter, and she calls me a new dad .She is a treasure beyond measure for me. I don’t deserve her in my le, but I’m totally thankful she accepts me. “She said, “Please, Doctor Wes, share my story to help others get the vaccine.”  Issuing his own warning for people to get the jab, he said: “Her le is forever changed...This is the reality of what can happen to a very young and totally healthy person. But he ended the thread on a slightly more positive tone. “Le goes on no matter how hard the curve balls are that we are thrown. There is hope for tomorrow. Love of her kids and sisters is driving her onwards, he said. “Very few drugs have such a great safety profile. Covid patients want to get vaccinated and many have asked you to reconsider... news weird-news how-get-rid-ghosts-your-"How to get rid of ghostsBySpectrum Paranormal InvestigationsEdited by Jo-Anne Rowney:,  Jun Updated:,  Oct | comments Think you have a ghost in your home  Well, thereaposs no need to panic.Before you go running to the phone seeking help from your local paranormal investigation team, there are a few things that you should do to establish whether you have a genuine haunting going on in your home or even place of work.All living creatures have a built-in alert system that triggers off when things just don’t seem right, Spectrum Paranormal Investigations team member Hazel Williams says.It’s an instinct that we possess and can give us a sense of fear that can escalate to the extent of paranoia. For humans, fear is something that we can describe to each other through stories about our experiences and one such scenario is that of the good old ghost story. These stories are recounted within every culture on earth and y descriptively on what you would have seen or encountered in accordance to your belief system.  At Spectrum Paranormal Investigations there are a set of protocols in place - things it requires from all clientele - before it takes on a case. Here the team shares the advice it gives to anybody who believes they have seen a ghost. Think your home is haunted  Share your own experiences in the comments below too. Step-by-step guide Firstly you have to take into account all factors surrounding your experience, these can range from your state of mind at that present time, to are you familiar with the location or has this experience taken place somewhere that you already believe to be haunted  Initial SightingTry to remember as much detail as possible, even though it may have been a terrying experience. This will help determine what type of encounter you may have had. Obtaining EvidenceIf you are still in the location and haven’t run for the hills! Then we would ask that as much evidence you could obtain would help. This could range from taking pictures to recording sounds of the environment.Helpful Equipment Within the field of paranormal investigating the EMFmeter is one such device used to detect changes to the environment looking for spikes at certain points when normally it would be dficult to obtain a reading these spikes are measured in milligauss, a unit of measurement of the magnetic-field and is also believed to be the field in which spirit energy moves around in. It is important to note that you are surrounded by magnetic fields, this radiates from the Earth’s core and envelops the Planet, also known as the Torus Energy Field!Seeking HelpThis could be a matter for your local spiritual leader or your local paranormal team. Do not in anyway try to make contact with the entity! Doing this could be disastrousthe spirit is malevolent. Read moreSafe PracticesWicca seems to be favoured by many as a way to ward off spirits, and the burning of sage and along with prayer is one such practice. The spraying of salt water in the air is used to discharge negative ion energy. Remember that good positive vibes in your home environment can help with creating positively charged energy. This could come in the form of relaxing music and filling your home with love and happiness when possible and not aggression. This will also stop any negative spirit from feeding on your misery.Never Do This You must never try to make direct contact with the spirit using means of communication such as Ouija or Seance unless you are fully trained in these methods. It is also advisable never to be under the influence of any kind of alcohol or drugs whilst trying to perform any of the above as you have to be sound of mind. Otherwise how could anyone take you seriously on this subject  acknowledging the supposed spirit will only give it access into your le. Albeit this could be in your subconscious mind until proven that a spirit is present! This could still have disastrous consequences and disrupt your daily well-being.  What evidence is there of ghosts  Evidence is always the key factor to any sighting. It’s basically detective work you have to rationalise all the factors involved first before jumping to the conclusion that you have seen a spirit. It is recommended you keep a diary of all activity from that moment on. Even though it may seem very insignicant at first, but over a period of four weeks we would normally see a pattern developing. Writing down such things like the times you see objects being moved when you know consciously know where it had previously been placed or evenyou begin to smell uncommon odours, in some cases people say it’s a putrid smell that of rotten eggs. When a loved one has passed away people often report the scent of flowers in the home and the odour of tobacco is reported in many cases. Remember, it’s very normal to feel that you are being watched from beyond the grave as we all have loved ones that have passed away and miss their presence. title: keep damp out your home
story: Keep damp out of your home this winter with tips that can save you £,Boiler experts have previously revealed the steps we should take when we first notice damp in our homes, from identying which type it is, to removing it and preventing it from appearing againOnce you know what type of damp it is, its vital its sorted quickly Image: iStockphotoByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsDamp can creep its way into any home, no matter what time of the year.But the problem can become increasingly worse in the colder months, as the wet weather forces us to hang our clothes inside to dry.When paired with the steam from showering or cooking, and leaks from gutters, pipes, and roofs, the amount of moisture increases which causes damp - but the longer you leave it, the worse itaposs likely to get, and the more costly it will be.Experts at Boiler Plan have previously revealed what signs you should look out for, what you can do to prevent it and how to get rid of each type. There are three main types of damp: condensation damp, rising damp and penetrating damp.Condensation dampCost to repair: £ - £, This is the most common form of damp found in homes, and occurs when hot air hits cold surfaces. To avoid it try to keep your house warm - perhaps put your heating onto a timer setting so it comes on periodically throughout the day. Also make sure to close the door when youaposre showering or cooking as this will avoid the moisture spreading to other rooms. You could also use moisture-resistant or anti-mould paint on areas that are likely to see high levels of moisture. If you are experiencing condensation damp, try to dry the areas as much as possible before wiping any mould with mould cleaner or with soapy water and a cloth not a brush. Then dry the area once again and leave a humidier running for as long as possible.  Rising dampCost to repair: £, - £,Rising damp iscaused by groundwater that moves up through your wall.Most walls have what’s called a ‘damp-proof course’ built into them, which blocks water from moving upwards through them, but rising damp can happenit’s ineffective, orthe course was never fitted to begin with. If you see any of the following signs, a new damp-proof course must be installed in your walls.A line of white salts on your walls Damp only on the lower half of your walls with a ‘tide-line’ above it Fluffy white salt on your walls Peeling paint and wallpaper Brown, crumbling plaster Skirting board damagePenetrating damp Cost to repair: £ - £ per room This occurs when leaks come in from the outside, like from poorly installed windows and doors, roofing issues, blocked gutters and leaking downpipes. To stop penetrating damp, check the following for any cracks, faults or defects and have them fixed:Flashing - this is where your roof meets your chimney Outer walls Your loft Roof Windows and doors - especially their frames Gutters, pipes and general drainage systemYou may also have penetrating dampyou notice any bubbled or wet plaster, which can occur straight after heavy rain or snow, and or cracks in masonry surfaces, renders or mortar joints. How to prevent damp in the bathroom The bathroom is one of the most common places to experience damp, especiallythe ventilation is poor. Boiler Plan has a few tips to keep damp at bay, including: Open a window Turn on an extractor fan Keep surfaces dry Fit air bricks - they have tiny holes in them, and can be fitted to exterior walls to allow air to pass through Use a humidier Use moisture-resistant or anti-mould paint Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it.
